Far from the town's tumultuous joys,</br>From boist'rous jollity and noise,</br>Grant me, ye Gods, an humble cell,</br>Where I and Happiness may dwell;</br>For she, good housewife!  hates to roam,</br>And always may be found at home.</br>No more to mix with Folly's train,</br>Whose pleasures all are light and vain:</br>She still delights to bring along</br>The vaunting tale, the roaring song,</br>The vacant grin, the simp'ring leer,</br>Opprobrious laugh, and taunting jeer,</br>With nonsense loud and riot blind,</br>And sure Repentance close behind.

Far from all joys, if joys be these,</br>O wrap me in inglorious ease,</br>Blest in some rural calm retreat,</br>With little box by way of seat;</br>Where pompous taste should ne'er be seen,</br>Its whole pretension to be clean;</br>And if it boast some useful pales,</br>Let others carve your zigzag rails;</br>My snug retirement still shall please,</br>Altho' its fashion's not Chinese.

Happy beneath my peaceful cot,</br>(No matter for the very spot)</br>Whether the vagrant fancy roves</br>O'er Berkshire hills and hanging groves,</br>Or Buck's fair vale, whose banks beside</br>The Tamus rolls her silver tide;</br>There let me live remote from strife,</br>A rural, not a hermit's life.

The Cock's shrill tone, or echoing horn,</br>Shall wake me by the break of morn,</br>While yet Aurora may be found,</br>Tripping o'er th' enamell'd ground;</br>Who, as she wanders o'er the mead,</br>Still hangs a pearl on every weed.</br>Then climbing up some steepy hill,</br>The curious eye shall gaze its fill;</br>While breaking from yon blushing skies,</br>The giant Sun begins to rise;</br>And, jocund as a bridegroom bold,</br>Laces the east with ruddy gold.</br>The tow'ring Lark in aether floats,</br>And warbles wild her raptur'd notes;</br>While perch'd upon a neigh'bring spray,</br>The Blackbird whistles out his lay,</br>'Till waken'd, all the groves along,</br>The feather'd choir take up the song.

Now Roger yokes his steeds to plow,</br>And drives them up yon mountain's brow;</br>Where I repair each morn by stealth,</br>To meet the rose-lip'd virgin Health;</br>Whom Temperance, in days of yore,</br>To lusty-sinew'd Labour bore:</br>Who woed and won the blithsome maid,</br>As at a harvest-home she play'd,</br>And to the pipe and tabor beat</br>Responsive measures with her feet.

Of work assigned their proper share,</br>The Labourers to the field repair;</br>While Colin, in the Farmer's yard,</br>Cleaves many a clump of stack-wood hard,</br>To make the chearful fire to burn,</br>And boil the pot, for their return.
With cleanly pail, and tuck'd up grown,</br>Now Dolly trips the village down;</br>And as she drives the cows along,</br>Beguiles her way with various song.

Hark!  how the horn, with merry sound,</br>Pierces the welkin all around,</br>While Echo, who still loves to mock,</br>(Blithe daughter of the hollow rock)</br>O'er hill and distant valley flies,</br>And doubles all the Hunter's cries,</br>See now the tim'rous Hare in view,</br>Whom horse and dogs and men pursue;</br>In vain she springs along the plain,</br>And doubles o'er the ground again;</br>In vain the friendly cover tries,—</br>Hark!  to the winding horn — she dies.

Let those who list in Folly's train,</br>Retirement's sober charms disdain;</br>Let them prefer tumultuous joys,</br>Where mirth is swallow'd up in noise;</br>Quaff draughts of strong Circaean wine,</br>And reel to bed from Bacchus' shrine,</br>Defrauding half the Night, to pay</br>Their debt of sleep to buxom Day;</br>In vain her silken charms are spread,</br>Be Sloth an exile from my bed;</br>Thus Health shall couple with delight,</br>And Exercise bring appetite.

Or let me in some evening still</br>Climb to the top of yon hoar hill,</br>E'er yet Hyperion's lusty beams</br>Have drank the salt of Tethy's streams;</br>Who standing on some mountain's brow,</br>Gilds here and there a vale below,</br>While struck with his declining rays,</br>The distant windows seem to blaze.

Oh!  could I boast the tuneful muse,</br>Whom the blest bard of Grongar woes,</br>Who stole her all-inchanted quill,</br>To paint the beauties of his hill,</br>Or his who deftly erst pourtray'd:</br>Sage Melancholy, matron stay'd,</br>And sung the goddess blithe and free</br>In heaven yclep'd Euphrosyne:</br>Whose pencil by gay Fancy tipt</br>In all the rainbows colours dipt,</br>Like the fam'd Thracian King of old,</br>Whate'er it touch'd transform'd to gold:</br>Then would I paint yon mountain's pride</br>Its prospect over champain wide,</br>O'er hill and dale, and forest brown,</br>With here and there a tufted town:</br>O'er fallow field and meadow green,</br>Chequ'ring the gay embroider'd scene;</br>While Tamasis his treasures pours,</br>Kissing the banks of either shores;</br>Who, winding still his current strong,</br>Sweeps the enamell'd vales along,</br>And o'er resisting locks, convey'd,</br>Beggars the garden's trim cascade.</br>Then would I speak, as Fancy roams,</br>Of villas neat, of lofty domes,</br>Of hamlet, and of village tell,</br>Where Contemplation loves to dwell.

But see the Night, in sable shroud,</br>Comes riding on yon dingy cloud;</br>Now flits the Bat with leathern wing,</br>Returning ever in a ring;</br>And whizzing thro' the dark'ned air,</br>The Rooks unto their nests repair;</br>Who love their merriment to hold</br>By some time-shaken abbey old,</br>Whose moss-grown turrets all around,</br>The oak or star-proof elm is found.

No more my wand'ring feet shall roam,</br>I'll hie me to my rustic home,</br>And thither shall my way be ta'en</br>Thro' some close and hedgy lane;</br>So shall the Nightingale the while</br>With dulcet song my walk beguile,</br>Who nightly to the moon complains</br>Trilling her soft melodious strains;</br>While all the village-bells around</br>Delight the ear with jocund sound.

But see the Toad forsakes her hole,</br>And loudly screams the staring Owl.</br>Hence let me hasten to my home,</br>(The dews forbid me now to roam)</br>So shall each day bring fresh delight,</br>And social converse crown the night.</br>
